description: Constructive Dilemma is a powerful inference rule that combines conditionals with a disjunction. If we know "if P then Q" AND "if R then S", and we also know "P or R" is true, then we can conclude "Q or S" must be true. This is a double-operation rule requiring two premises.
rule_pattern: (P → Q) ∧ (R → S), P ∨ R ⊢ Q ∨ S

problems.solution: Apply Constructive Dilemma directly: since either P or R is true, and we have conditionals for both, we get Q or S.
Apply Constructive Dilemma with different variables.
Apply Constructive Dilemma - order of disjunction doesn't matter, result may be reversed.
Apply Constructive Dilemma where one antecedent is a conjunction.
Apply Constructive Dilemma where consequents are conjunctions.
First apply Conjunction to combine the two implications, then Constructive Dilemma.
Apply Constructive Dilemma to get Q ∨ S, then use the additional conditionals to derive T.
Apply Constructive Dilemma with complex disjunctions as antecedents.
Complex multi-step: use Modus Ponens on P → Q to try getting Q. If ¬Q, then use ¬Q → R and Modus Ponens to get R, then R → S to get S. Use Constructive Dilemma strategically.
